channel.title: Parents and your future
channel.description:
Hello MoparScape.
It's been a while since I posted a debate topic so I thought I'd get on posting one. This topic has been on my mind for quite a while and I can't come to a conclusion. Should our parents have a say in how we live or lives and plan our futures?
For example, my dad wants me to go out to Afghanistan and work with him; however my mum hates the fact that my dad is out there and wants me to stay at uni and get my degrees before making any bigger life decisions.
When I first told my dad I didn't think I'd be going out there with him he had this massive argument with me about how I was his son and should do what he says.
So, what so you, moparians? Should parents have a say in our future or not?

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:26, topic:459262”][quote author=RiiPiiNFtW link=topic=562166.msg4102205#msg4102205 date=1347632322]
I am taking care of my dads house and she stopped by to pick me up and she said be ready in 8 minutes. Then my dad calls me asking to find something and mail it to him. I also have to care for the cats and that takes 15 minutes alone. I couldn’t find what my dad needed and my mom was complaining about being tired so I told her to go home. So for being nice and for that reason, I was kicked out of her house since I don’t “love” her.
[/quote]

that’s pretty bad, lol.[/quote]Now shes going to the police department to try to get me out of my dad’s house so I can spend time with here. dafuq

Read full topic

Our parents should be able to influence us, but not dictate us. (In this aspect, at least.)

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:20, topic:459262”][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=562166.msg4101896#msg4101896 date=1347584784]

[quote author=Ruby link=topic=562166.msg4099507#msg4099507 date=1347279904]Should parents have a say in our future or not?

Imho, unless the kid is willing to move out and cut off financial support from the parents he should not only take all advise that his parents give him, but also follow with the parent’s plan.

aaaaah a bit of financial blackmail
[/quote]
hey, if my parents want to pay for my college I’ll make damn sure I get a high GPA.
[/quote]
You just make me love my country even more. No need for financial support from parents to get a decent education.[/quote]
I love how you assume I do get financial support from my parents. They won’t pay for my college, I’ll have to pay for it myself.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

It’s important to listen to your parents. My parents want the best for me but I get annoyed with it. My brother went through the same thing I am going through right now and he says just suck it up and listen to them. Parent’s have lots of real world knowledge.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @F_A_I_L_S Fails
item.description:
@F_A_I_L_S wrote:

My parents have told me the same thing for years. “We want you to be more successful than we are” See, both of my parents never got their high-school diploma(s), but the thing is… they both have decent jobs. My dad works at the Toyota plant in Indiana and my mom does private duty. What that means is… she works with elderly people when the caregiver doesn’t want to put them in a nursing home. The person she is currently ‘taking care’ of is the founder of a the Messenger Inquirer, not that it has anything to with the subject at-hand.

I guess what i’m trying to say is, after you get a high-school Diploma your career should be up to you from there. There’s nothing wrong with your parents wanting you to go into a certain field, thinking it would be the best for you. When you turn 18, you’re considered an adult and should be wise enough to have your future planned.

When I graduate I plan on moving close to the penitentiary and working there as a Correction Officer. It’s not the best career but i’ve had my mind on it for quite sometime now, and I am certain that’s what I plan on doing until I retire. It’s something I want to do, and both my parents approve.

I hope this helped… somewhat.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Kastro1 wrote:

I think that yes parents should have a say in what they want you to do in the future but they leave it on to ourselves on what we wish to approach in the future; at the end of the day its our life, so we should be able to live it how we wish.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

What Bowser said, this is a big problem in Egypt – you will often find people forced to study something they don’t like just because their parents want them to, or they’re forced to give up something they like (sports come to mind almost immediately). I think they should provide advice (they do have experience, after all) but they should also learn when they can’t completely control your life any more and when they should leave you make your own decisions.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Parents should only prevent you from taking really stupid decisions, not forcing you into US imperialism or taking a specific university degree.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @amy_webb1 amy_webb
item.description:
@amy_webb1 wrote:

I believe that once the child is mentally capable of making their own decisions and is able to understand the effect it may have on their life, that they can from then on decide for themselves. It is usually at about the age of 16 they begin to take charge of their own life but it isn’t like that for all kids.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents and your future
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

Soulcist:

I think the two should have a couple on our lives, not hold our “souls” if you will in their hands after we’re 18 or something. At that point, we are somewhat mature to make our own decisions. Obviously if we don’t want to do something, we’re not going to do it, and if we’re forced to do it, we’re not going to remain in the ‘field’ for long, now are we?

Yeah I agree with that, but I think that after 16 we should really be loosened up on if you will, they shouldn’t be as rough and let us find our own way in the world. I mean, I realise they don’t want us to make the same mistakes as they have and what not but they don’t realise that we have to learn ourselves.

That’s just my opinion, though.

Read full topic
